title: Understanding Fibroids
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Fibroids (also called uterine myomas or leiomyomas) are non-cancerous growths that develop in or around the uterus. They are very common, especially in women of reproductive age.

content.title: Key Facts
content.description: Fibroids are almost always benign (non-cancerous). They vary in size from tiny seedlings to large masses. Many women have fibroids without knowing it.

content.value: Many fibroids cause no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they may include:

items: Frequent urination or difficulty emptying the bladder

content.title: When to Seek Help
content.description: See a doctor if you have heavy periods, pain, or difficulty with bladder or bowel function.

content.value: Fibroids are classified by their location in the uterus.

items.title: Intramural Fibroids
items.description: Grow within the muscular wall of the uterus. Most common type.

items.title: Subserosal Fibroids
items.description: Grow on the outer surface of the uterus. Can press on nearby organs.

items.title: Submucosal Fibroids
items.description: Grow into the inner cavity of the uterus. Can cause heavy bleeding.

items.title: Pedunculated Fibroids
items.description: Attached to the uterus by a stalk. Can grow inside or outside the uterus.

content.value: The exact cause is unknown, but your risk may be higher if you:

items: Have a family history of fibroids
Are of African or Caribbean heritage

content.title: Hormonal Connection
content.description: Fibroids are linked to estrogen and progesterone. They often grow during reproductive years and shrink after menopause.

content.value: Most women with fibroids can conceive and have healthy pregnancies. However, fibroids may sometimes affect fertility or pregnancy outcomes.

items: Submucosal fibroids may interfere with implantation
Large fibroids may change the shape of the uterus
Some fibroids may increase risk of miscarriage
Fibroids may grow during pregnancy due to hormones

content.title: Planning Pregnancy
content.description: If you have fibroids and are planning to become pregnant, discuss your options with a specialist.

content.value: Living with fibroids can affect your emotional health and quality of life. Heavy bleeding, pain, and concerns about fertility can cause stress and anxiety.

content.title: Support Available
content.description: Don't hesitate to talk to your doctor about how fibroids are affecting you. Support groups and counselling can also help.

content.value: Treatment depends on fibroid size, location, symptoms, and whether you want to have children.

items.title: Watchful Waiting
items.content: If fibroids are small and not causing symptoms, monitoring may be recommended.

items.title: Medication
items.content: Hormonal treatments to manage symptoms. Pain relievers for discomfort. Iron supplements for anemia from heavy bleeding.

items.title: Non-invasive Procedures
items.content: MRI-guided focused ultrasound to destroy fibroid tissue. Uterine artery embolization to cut off blood supply.

items.title: Surgical Options
items.content: Myomectomy (removal of fibroids while preserving uterus). Hysterectomy (removal of uterus) for severe cases.

content.value: While medical treatment may be needed, lifestyle changes can help manage symptoms.

items.title: Maintain healthy weight
items.description: Excess weight is linked to fibroid growth

items.title: Eat a balanced diet
items.description: Include plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains

items.title: Manage stress
items.description: Relaxation techniques can help with pain

content.title: Remember
content.description: Fibroids are very common and treatable. If symptoms are affecting your life, speak to a healthcare provider about your options.
